Description: Lesson Plan Topics: Facts vs. Opinion, Evaluating scientific explanations.  Includes hook with think, pair-share, class discussion, science inquiry in mixed-ability groups, and extensions.
Great intermediate examples of scientific explanations that align with Common Core.
Great advanced examples of scientific explanations that align with Common Core.
Great basic examples of scientific explanations that align with Common Core.
Class demonstration to introduce the steps of the scientific method, focusing on developing hypotheses.
Graphic organizer for the scientific method.
Lab follows the steps of the scientific method and focuses on hypothesizing.

File Name: Ocean Motion: Lesson 1 "Navigating the Ocean" Teacher Guide
Resource Name: Ocean Motion: Lesson 1 "Navigating the Ocean" Teacher Guide
Authors: Ocean Motion: David Snyder - Gallaudet University, Nancy Smaroff - Bridging the Watershed, M. Sara Tweedie - Tweedie & Associates
Description: Students determine longitude and latitude using the Sun's shadow and an online calculator, then investigate ocean surface currents effect on drifting objects.  Includes pre and post assessment, student investigation, and answer keys.

File Name: Ocean Motion: Lesson 1 "Navigating the Ocean" Student Guide
Resource Name: Ocean Motion: Lesson 1 "Navigating the Ocean" Student Guide
Authors: Ocean Motion: David Snyder - Gallaudet University, Nancy Smaroff - Bridging the Watershed, M. Sara Tweedie - Tweedie & Associates
Description: Online student guide for Ocean Motion: Lesson 1 "Navigating the Ocean".
Design a paper rocket propelled by Alka-Seltzer® and water to demonstrate Newton's third law of motion.
Student activity sheet for use with Alka Rockets Lesson Plan.
Lesson plan covers rocks and the processes of the rock cycle.
Student activity in which students are asked to name the parts of the rock cycle.
Lesson plan covers the different types of igneous rocks and their classification.
Classification chart for Igneous Rock Lesson Plan lab.

Students explore the effects of pressure and heat in the formation of different types of metamorphic rock.  Lesson includes: 3 simulation activities, extension activity, and students questions and answer key.

Resource Name: Ocean Motion: Lesson 2 "Traveling on a Rotating Sphere"
Authors: Ocean Motion: David Snyder - Gallaudet University, Nancy Smaroff - Bridging the Watershed, M. Sara Tweedie - Tweedie & Associates (http://www.oceanmotion.org/guides/cf_2/cf_teacher_2.htm#WhatDoYouKnow)
Description: Students investigate the relationship between Earth's rotation, convection, the Coriolis Effect, and trade winds.  Includes pre and post assessment with answer keys, and student investigation.

Resource Name: Student Guide to Ocean Motion: Lesson 2 "Traveling on a Rotating Sphere"
Authors: David Snyder - Gallaudet University, Nancy Smaroff - Bridging the Watershed, M. Sara Tweedie - Tweedie & Associates (http://www.oceanmotion.org/guides/cf_2/cf_student_2.htm)
Description: Online student guide for Ocean Motion: Lesson 2 "Traveling on a Rotating Sphere".

Resource Name: Structure Of The Earth Lesson Plan
Authors: The University of Tennessee at Martin
Description: Students learn about the layers of the Earth by constructing a model.
Covers: what are plates? How do they move? What are the three types of plate boundaries?
Students explore plate boundaries using food and an online simulation.
Includes a hands-on activity in which students explore folds and faults and learn how to represent them on maps and cross sections. Includes student activity worksheet.

Resource Name: How to Make a Mountain Lesson Plan
Description: Students investigate how the shape of mountains can vary and how that shape provides evidence about its origin and history.

Students will learn about the four types of seismic waves, their characteristics and effects. Then students predict the level of damage each wave might cause in a residential area and test their predictions against several computer animations.

Resource Name: Faults are at Fault: Where Earthquakes Occur Lesson Plan
Description: Students plot the locations of faults and then map recent earthquakes in order to see the relationship between earthquakes and faults at plate boundaries.

Resource Name: Examining All the Factors Lesson Plan
Description: Students investigate earthquakes of the past and analyze data to determine the predictability of future quakes.

Resource Name: The Science of Tsunamis: Seeking Understanding in the Wake of Tragedy Lesson Plan
Description: Students investigate wave propagation and recent tsunami disasters.  Lesson includes a class demonstration, an online student activity, and extension activity.

Resource Name: A Whole Lot of Shakin' Goin' On! Lesson Plan
Description: Students collect data to compare the 1906 and 1989 California earthquakes, and determine the factors that influence the amount of shaking that occurs in an area due to an earthquake.

Resource Name: Landslides, Liquefaction, and Structural Failure Lesson Plan
Description: Students explore the various types of damage that can occur from an earthquake and understand why certain areas and structures are more prone to damage than others.
Students explore how volcanoes are formed through examining plate boundaries and hot spots.

Resource Name: Science Italian Style: Eruption! Lesson Plan
Description: What determines lava flow?  Students explore this question through experimentation with viscosity of liquids.
Students measure the viscosity of various liquids through a hands-on lab. Worksheets are included for students to record data, analyze results, and calculate the standard deviation.
Procedures for Viscosity Lab that is part of the Viscosity Lesson Plan.
Student Data Table Worksheet for use with the Viscosity Lesson Plan Lab.
Student Histogram Worksheet.
Students work in groups to learn about the three major types of volcanoes. Includes links to an interactive slide show and virtual field trip.
Hands-on lab for students to explore how lava contributes to various forms of topography.
Student worksheet for Lava Layering Lab.
Students determine the effects of erosion on regolith formation and deposition on Earth as well as regolith formation on the Moon by meteoritic activity.
Student Handout for Lab activity in Regolith Formation Lesson Plan.

Authors: The University of Tennessee at Martin
Description: In this lesson, students will explore the causes and effects of physical and chemical weathering and compare and contrast erosion which results from the action of wind, ice, and water.

Authors: The University of Tennessee at Martin
Description: In this lesson, students will discover how soil is formed, be able to describe the differences in soils in terms of texture, mineral content, and where the soil was formed, and identify and describe the parts of a soil profile.

Resource Name: Contaminants in the Water Cycle Lesson Plan
Description: Students review the water cycle, investigate how the water supply of a region can become contaminated, and suggest possible ways to improve water quality.

Resource Name: Floods: Rising Waters and You Lesson Plan
Authors: American Field Guide: Oregon Public Broadcasting and PBS
Description: Students examine how floods work and why they can cause so much damage. They will use a stream table to observe the processes that lead to flooding and the effects of floods on human-made structures.

Resource Name: Density: Sea Water Mixing & Sinking Lesson Plan
Description: Students discover hoe salinity and temperature relate to ocean circulation.  Lesson includes background information, a concept map, student activities, and assessments.

Resource Name: Ocean Habitats: The Intertidal Zone Lesson Plan
Authors: American Field Guide: Oregon Public Broadcasting and PBS
Description: This unit features 4 lessons that focus on life in the intertidal zone.  Lessons include background information, activities, videos, assessments and answer keys.

Resource Name: Ocean Motion: Lesson 3 "Data to Information" Teacher's guide Lesson Plan
Authors: Ocean Motion: David Snyder - Gallaudet University, Nancy Smaroff - Bridging the Watershed, M. Sara Tweedie - Tweedie & Associates
Description: Students explore how the ocean influences weather and climate through on an online investigation and analysis of data. Pre and post assessments with answer keys are provided.

Resource Name: Ocean Motion: Lesson 3 "Data to Information" Student's guide
Authors: Ocean Motion: David Snyder - Gallaudet University, Nancy Smaroff - Bridging the Watershed, M. Sara Tweedie - Tweedie & Associates
Description: Online student guide for Ocean Motion: Lesson 3

Resource Name: Trouble in the Troposphere - A Lesson on Tropospheric Ozone Lesson Plan
Description: Students use data to create graphs comparing the ozone levels in various US cities, analyze and evaluate trends, and determine how humans have affected air quality and what steps can be done to preserve air quality.  Lesson includes vocabulary, background information, activity, online resources and extension.

Resource Name: Clouds and Solar Radiation Lesson Plan
Authors: Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma
Description: Students analyze satellite images and solar radiation measurements to determine cloud coverage, location, and movement.

In this National Geographic lesson, students will use data to learn about and analyze tornado activity throughout the US. The lesson includes online interactive links, student activity, assessment and extension activity.

Resource Name: Do You Want to Risk It? Lesson Plan
Description: Students examine the history of natural disasters in given areas and determine the risk of natural disasters considering population increase and its impact. Lesson includes: activity, student worksheet, and teacher notes.

Resource Name: Ama-Zone! The Rain Forest Project Lesson Plan
Description: Students participate in a role play simulation to debate the possibility of establishing a world preserve. Students explore the human impacts on the rain forest and learn how the rain forest effects us.  Worksheets included.

Resource Name: Biomagnification in the Great Lakes Ecosystems Lesson Plan
Description: This lesson focuses on biomagnification as it relates to the ecosystems of the Great Lakes region in the mid-western United States. The lesson includes student activity, suggested assessments and extensions, and related links.

Resource Name: Marine Food Chains and Biodiversity Lesson Plan
Description: Students use marine organism cards and trophic level classifications to identify and describe food chains in several marine ecosystems.
Students investigate various marine ecosystems, identify their characteristics, and locate the ecosystems on a map of the world's oceans.
Students explore various hypotheses concerning the extinction of the woolly mammoth.

Resource Name: What Did T. Rex Taste Like? Lesson Plan
Authors: Regents of the University of California
Description: Students explore cladistics through the process of organizing living things by common ancestry and evolutionary relationships. Students will gain a better understanding of diversity of life and evolutionary history.

Resource Name: Ocean Habitats: The Intertidal Zone Lesson Plan
Authors: American Field Guide: Oregon Public Broadcasting and PBS
Description: This unit features 4 lessons that focus on life in the intertidal zone and how organisms living there have adapted to their environment.  Lessons include background information, activities, videos, assessments and answer keys.

Resource Name: Getting Into the Fossil Record Lesson Plan
Authors: Regents of the University of California
Description: Students gain a basic understanding of what a fossil is and the factors involved in becoming part of the fossil record. Includes: pre and post assessment with key, student activity with handouts and teacher guide.

Resource Name: Stories From the Fossil Record Lesson Plan
Authors: Regents of the University of California
Description: Students gain a basic understanding of how fossils can be used to interpret the past. They will explore: Biodiversity, Geologic Time, Paleoecology, and Past Lives.

Authors: Regents of the University of California
Description: Students take an informational tour to gain a basic understanding of geologic time, the evidence for events in Earth’s history, relative and absolute dating techniques, and the significance of the Geologic Time Scale.

Resource Name: Introduction to Energy Resources Lesson Plan
Description: Students explore kinetic and potential energy in an online simulation.  The law of conservation of energy is explored in an enrichment activity.

Resource Name: Energy Sources and Energy Use Lesson Plan
Description: In this National Geographic lesson, students discuss the relationship between energy usage and pollution, reflect on their own energy usage and sort energy sources as renewable or nonrenewable. This lesson includes background information, vocabulary, and student activities.

Resource Name: Automobile Choices And Alternative Fuels Lesson Plan
Description: Students explore various types of alternative fuels and their effect on the environment, lifestyles, and finances and use this information to participate in a multi-step car buying decision.

Resource Name: Energy Conservation and Efficiency Lesson Plan
Description: Lesson Plan for Energy Conservation and Efficiency.

In this lesson, students will survey their homes for hazardous materials and tally the results as a class, research proper waste disposal methods and learn about the potential consequences of improper disposal.

Resource Name: Mercury in the Environment Lesson Plan
Description: Students will examine human-related sources of mercury in the environment, dangerous contaminants from coal, and the dangers of mercury in humans.  Lesson includes: background information, video, lab, and online resources with student handouts.

Resource Name: Are The World's Weather And Climate Changing? Lesson Plan
Description: Students learn about and analyze weather patterns and weather cycles to hypothesize about climate change.  This lesson includes a pre-assessment, discussion, research, and student activity.
Students calculate their age according to planetary orbits.
This activity is designed to help students understand that weight is a measurement of gravitational attraction.
Students use photographs taken from the Viking Orbiter Spacecraft to identify various landforms on Mars.  Includes student worksheet and answer key.
Students investigate the impact of asteroids in this hands-on lesson.  The lesson includes an answer key.

Resource Name: The Future of the Milky Way Lesson Plan
Description: Students research collisions of galaxies, changes in stars, and black holes then discuss the future of the Milky Way given their research.  The lesson includes background information, activity, vocabulary, and assessment.

Resource Name: Life's Big Questions: How Did the Universe Begin? Lesson Plan
Description: Students explore the origins of the universe through three hands-on activities, a writing exercise, and extension activities.  Questions and answers are provided.
